instruction: What kinds of spectra were used in the related study that aimed to estimate the modal mineralogy of mixtures on the surface of the asteroid (101955) Bennu?
Output: The study used MIR (mid-infrared) spectra from the OSIRIS-REx Thermal Emission Spectrometer (OTES) to estimate the modal mineralogy of mixtures on the surface of the asteroid (101955) Bennu.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study that aimed to estimate the modal mineralogy of mixtures on the surface of the asteroid (101955) Bennu?
Output: PLS and lasso spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to estimate the modal mineralogy of mixtures on the surface of the asteroid Bennu.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the models in the related study that aimed to estimate the modal mineralogy of mixtures on the surface of the asteroid (101955) Bennu, and how accurate were the predictions of the mineralogy on Bennu's surface?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the models was the cross-validated root-mean-square error. The final PLS models had a range of similar to 4 to 13 vol% for the root-mean-square error, depending on the mineral group. 

The predictions of the mineralogy on Bennu's surface were found to be 78% phyllosilicate, 9% olivine, 11% carbonates, and 6% magnetite in terms of volume percentage. It should be noted that pyroxene was not predicted for the global average spectrum, although small amounts of it have been detected on Bennu. These predictions confirm previous findings that Bennu's composition is consistent with CI/CM chondrites with high degrees of aqueous alteration. The mineralogy of two previously identified OTES spectral types varied minimally from the global average, indicating that the spectral differences are primarily caused by relative abundances of fine particulates rather than major compositional variations.

instruction: How did the researchers use machine learning multivariate analysis to estimate the surface mineralogy of the asteroid (101955) Bennu using OSIRIS-REx Thermal Emission Spectrometer (OTES) data?
Output: The researchers used two types of machine learning multivariate analysis, namely partial least squares (PLS) and least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (lasso), to estimate the surface mineralogy of the asteroid (101955) Bennu using OSIRIS-REx Thermal Emission Spectrometer (OTES) data. They built MIR spectral models using these machine learning techniques.

instruction: Can the machine learning multivariate analysis using OSIRIS-REx Thermal Emission Spectrometer (OTES) data be considered a superior method for estimating the surface mineralogy of the asteroid (101955) Bennu compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the machine learning multivariate analysis using OSIRIS-REx Thermal Emission Spectrometer (OTES) data can be considered a superior method for estimating the surface mineralogy of the asteroid (101955) Bennu compared to traditional methods. The study mentioned in the text used partial least squares (PLS) and least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (lasso), two types of machine learning, to build MIR spectral models. The results showed that the PLS models outperformed the lasso models in estimating the mineralogy. The cross-validated root-mean-square error of the final PLS models ranged from 4 to 13 vol% depending on the mineral group. These findings suggest that machine learning multivariate analysis provides more accurate predictions of the surface mineralogy of Bennu compared to traditional methods.
